												Empty servers, toxic community, a developer that keeps making the game worse and a publisher that only cares to milk the customers.Ok let's write some more stuff about the game that I have spend few thousands of hours the last years (ignore my steam playtime...).The game itself is pretty decent, with outdated but still pretty graphics and a tab targetting combat system that works very well most of the time. The problem is that it started as a game with a strong focus on aerial combat, to stand out from the rest mmos but NCSoft with the updates turned it into a generic mmo and made aerial combat a secondary aspect of the game that many players never really experience. NCsoft also focus on making the game appeal more to anime fans instead of actually improving it for everyone. It looks more and more like Tera,etc...just look at all the skins the last years! Also while with each update they try to make the game less grindy and easier to new players, those players will have to face a game design problem that got introduced with patch 4: the pvp gear is restricted to high ranked players and it's impossible for new players to reach high rank in most servers. It's only possible on dead servers, but why would you play on a dead server anyway? One big problem the game always had is its community: unfriendly, toxic, with daily drama on public chat channels. The old players will not invite you in their groups, they will never help you in the end game. It's the worst community I have ever seen.Second big problem is the faction balance. At the moment every server is unbalanced, they are all dominated by the elyos faction, that's why Gameforge tries to make people roll on asmodian faction. But I believe the publisher cannot fix this problem, as its created by the game design and the bad community: the two factions should cooperate to balance the servers but instead the elyos faction is  always greedy, dominating the fort sieges, increasing even more the gap between the two factions in terms of gear,etc.The publisher doesnt do much to improve the situation. They promised server merges after a long time of players requesting them, only to announce they gonna delay the merges cause of the steam release...They do nothing against the cheaters, when even some player was able to develop a tool that can detect them (aidpsmeter). They keep making pay2win events that give valuable items only to those that spend loads of euros. They restrict way too much the new players that do not have a gold pack, to prevent the gold sellers, which kinda works but those restrictions should be lifted when a player reaches some certain level. Their workaround for this problem for the steam release is the free 15 days gold pack, but they should get a better solution. Also their support is one of the worst you will have to deal with, they are usually clueless and refuse to help you with things that NCsoft support would deal with in minutes. I will never forget that I got a perma ban for ...jumping on a rock! and i had to make a video to show to their support...how to jump on that specific rock for my ban to get lifted...they still banned me for 2 weeks cause apparently jumping on rocks in considered a 'bug abuse'. They also love to ban people for 'offensive' language, even for words like 'noob' or other words that are not really considered offensive in the real life world...A good thing is that its not heavily pay2win like many other free2play mmos. With the exception of those stupid p2w events that Gameforge has introduced lately, a player can have everything without spending any real life money on this game. Gold packs can also be bought from other players with the ingame currency. I personally have only bought cosmetic stuff and mounts from their cash-shop.So what is started as a very interesting mmo, is now another dying generic mmo, managed by an incompetent publisher. I can't recommend it, especially when there are so many other mmos, but hey, its free to try it for yourselves!

												Although Aion is not in the best state at the moment, it’s still an amazing game and still very much playable for veterans and newbies alike. This is one of those games that if you played it when it first came out, years would pass, you would try multiple other MMOs and realize that you keep coming back to Aion. The main problem that the game has now ( and pretty much the only really major problem ) is that, while there still is a decent amount of players, they are scattered among 16 different servers, which with some exceptions are all kinda underpopulated. There are merges promised though for january/february which would make the situation better, but they were delayed once before, plus I’m not sure how competent the publisher is in that regard so I’ll just leave it at that.Overall it’s a fast paced tab targetting PvPvE mmorpg, that has the classic “holy trinity” roles in the party. Leveling can get kinda boring at times, but getting to the level cap of 65 is fast and the main fun lies in the endgame.PvEwise: There are plenty of instanced dungeons you can go to and most are doable and manageable to find a group to. There are of course more challenging ones.PvPwise: PvP gameplay in general is deep and very enjoyable even if classes aren’t perfectly balanced in 1v1’s. Word pvp exists, but not super active right now, since maps are deserted, due to low population of the servers (merges might fix that in a way at least) and a lack of engagement in current endgame areas. Instanced pvp is hella fun though. There are tons of instanced pvp arenas and battlegrounds, which open daily/weekly. Sieges, a zergy battle between the two factions for fortresses, can be fun too, but most servers are Elyos dominated, so sieges are very often one-sided and I don’t see any change to that anytime soon to be honest.The patch is 4.8 and 4.x has been here for a while now, so as a new player you’ll meet some players that outgear you, which might be frustrating since gear plays a big part in this game, but having a general mmorpg know-how should be enough to get competitive in not that long period of time.To sum it up: if you have the patience to wait for merges and can stomach a pretty hands down publisher give it a go, if not wait for the merges, hopefully the game will get healthier then.P.S most of the negative reviews the game gets are caused by the publisher, not by the game itself

Even the guy with the 1.3k+ steam products hasn't stopped playing it since its release. The game is highly addictive and challenging. It takes a while to gear up at first and the ranking system isn't exactly friendly to starting players, but it pays off with hours of fun experiences, explorations, and fights. It really has taken a nosedive in the past few years in terms of population and this is like a last attempt at saving the game and I do suggest everyone give it a try.Lastly, if you do get banned right after registering/without doing anything wrong - don't worry, just write a ticket to their support and you will usually get unbanned in a few minutes. 												Ive played Aion for over a year now and I would also like to point out some things.First things first Gameforge (or Failforge) is the main evil to this game with there every chance to money grab and put minimal effort into everything. Cut Gameforge out of the picture and most of the Pay2Win elements disappear. If your are able to go play the NA, NCSoft version, go do it, thats if you don't mind bots stealing your kills and complete amateurs that think there all pro ruining most of your runs. You often get the feeling that Gameforge doesn't care about there players or the servers as long as they can give you a false sense of security that they are trying to makes things better, so you fork over the cash (it frustrates us all). That said under all the mess this is an AMAZING game and you can really get sucked into its world. Aion is a fast paced open world PvPvE MMORPG ...WITH ADDED FLIGHT, using the classic classes, with some really interesting twists to make them unique. The world is split into 3 major fractions 2 of them are playable and have different story lines and maps.The fractions are:  Elyos, living in luxury with all the beautiful sunlight. (Playable) Asomdians, exiled and forced to adapt to living in the darkness. (Playable) Bulaur, the bigger evil that only have the desire to dominate. (NPC based) The higher level you go the more PvP action is available but in some places leveling can be slow and quite boring. with some know how this can be avoided if you know where to level at set times. I suggest following a leveling guide from off the web if you are making your first character.For any new players i strongly suggest you avoid starting with a Templar and Cleric they are the most expensive classes as they require different sets of gear to be played well. Also try to avoid using Assassin and Sorcerer as your first character because they are the harder classes to play and require a lot of skill and knowledge about the game.The Crafting system is one of the best ways to make a lot of money, but can get quite tedious and boring, its also very time consuming and has been promised to be improved some time in the future.The Guild/Legion system is fun and does the job but your limited to what you can do and can be frustrating coming form a guild owners point of view. Also been promised to be improved.The Housing system is grate and very well done, better than I first expected. Unfortunately most players are not so interested in it. Some world events are rather fun and keep you entertained and others can seam dull, boring and a waste of time or Pay2Win.PvE: There is plenty of instances to keep you busy, some easy some rather challenging. sadly only few let you go in without a group but they are all do-able. Some instances do include some PvP but not until you reach the higher levels.PvP: PvP goes into grate depths and is fun, enjoyable and sometimes can really get your heart pounding. There is a nice amount of PvP instances and battlegrounds you can enter daily/weekly. World PvP exists from levels 25+ but can be avoided using the "rookie server" up until level 55 if you wish. Big siege events call for all out war against the opposing fractions to capture fortresses and give guilds some where to place there name on the world giving them certain rewards and bonuses for there fraction.Thanks to NCSoft some big changes in the updates soon to come will fix all of the games major issues, besides Gameforge. Like..Even though it says free to play, this game use to be a subscription game and remains that way. If you continue to play free you will only get a demo version of the full game, until you buy a "Gold Pack" that lifts all restrictions, oh ..there also tradeable :/ . At the moment this is causing economy problems because there is no way to to trade items with other players without one but they are looking into ways make it possible to lift the trade restrictions, without currency sellers abusing it. Right now there is a population problem, although there is a decent amount of players altogether, the world is rather empty because everyone is spread out across 16 servers. This is being solved by merging a lot of the servers together and the whole point of bringing this game to steam ..to bring in more players. They plan to go through the merge in Jan/Feb time. 												Played hundreds of hours from 4.0 to 4.5 - unfortunatly can not recommend this game! Well it was fun in the beginning but after a friend shown me GuildWars2 I realised the amount of mistakes Aion has is unforgivable.== BASICS ==Let's start with the basics: Aion is a generic themepark MMO with PvE AND PvP and high progression. When you start you will do kill and gather-quests, which used to be fun in the beginning but becomes boring grind in the middle game. Combat is traditional tab-1-2-win, nothing that challenges. In a nutshell you don't have any freedom or open-world, but only a campaign that leads you from point A to B. In endgame (quest-)grind becomes ridiculous, you accept a quest, kill 15 mobs and return, nothing more. If you expect challenging PvE-content or Openworld, this is wrong game!== ENDGAME ==does not exist.. well that's my opinion. Actually the game has high complexity, there are many upgrade options that you really have to deserve to get. The game has a lot of equip to farm, skins to collect, ways to improve your character, but well .. there are only few dungeons worth to play. When I completed my equip I stood there like "so what do I do now? I saw every dungeon, and now?".== PVP ==Now for PvP: Aion used to have a really cool OpenPvP when I started. You always felt the adrenaline when you entered PvP-Areas with your mates and group-combats were exciting as hell. Aion is GROUP COMBAT only, and just to defend this game a bit, classes are UNBALLANCED, because teamwork always will lead you to survive.On the other hand, when 4.0 you are thrown in the one-and-only PvP map which feels like a giant arena full of zergs and gankers, because the real problem is that starters are killed within seconds by the veterans who already have high equip but can't match with their league. Maps are small, it's really difficult to keep covered, gankers are just waiting for you. So if you want to enjoy Open World PvP, you really have to be patiently until you have something that's better than your starter gear. But in a nutshell, Gear > Skill.In Arenas there's NO MATCHMAKING, you want to level but fight against a veteran / you want to have heavy pvp but fight against a rookie who will go afk because it's senseless. Aion should not have an arena at all.. and really not call itself a "PvP"-Game like the Gameforge Launcher does.Seriously, this was the point when I decided to quit. Although I had the equip to fight against most of opponents, I expect skill in a PvP-Game. Tournaments are not possible, I recommend Blade&Soul or GW2 if you want to.== COMMUNITY ==Toxic. But that was predictable in a PvP-game which rewards solo-players and idiots who give a♥♥♥♥♥♥about teamplay. Pleasant people just leave and go to GW2, FFXIV, ArcheAge and TESO, idiots stay. I don't know the reason exactly and I don't want to waste any more time thinking about.== LAST BUT NOT LEAST ==When you want to play PvP, you have to run dungeons (PvE) to farm your equip, when you want to play PvE, you have to go through the PvP-zones. Aion tries to mix PvP with PvE, but seriously, it doesnt make any sense! The game is only recommendable for both, PvP AND PvE gamers who need progression, easy gameplay that never overwhelmes and grind that always give you your daily serving of confirmation.PS:This review was edited few times. When you don't agree with me, feel free to comment.

												I really liked AION up until it got itself on Steam. I'll be honest. It feels a bit annoying as because I couldn't log in with my old details, and for some reason wasn't even able to recover my old account. So that did feel terrible, and led to a boring grind to try and get back where I was.Okay. So whole technical thing out of the way. AION is an absolutely BEAUTIFUL RPG for a free-to-play. And features some of the most beautiful graphics I've ever seen in an RPG. I won't give too much credit to it, as there are more graphically advanced games out there now, but as FTP games go, this probably has the most beautiful environment even on lower graphic settings.As for gameplay... I didn't really get much from it as far as I managed to get. It felt slow, and quests felt like a hideous chore as fights felt slow and tedious, which is irritating for an RPG with fighting elements. And the early quests... really felt like you got nowhere (bear in mind I played this before it got on to Steam). I did however try to get as much from the start as possible. I would maybe have liked an easier progression so that you weren't skipping quests to save so much time.Going on to controls, I liked how the game was controlled, and liked the familiar layout of an RPG. It felt like a game that could easily be played. Camera was easy to control, and made the whole game feel so much smoother.Character customisation... I wouldn't complain about it so much if it had more options so that it wasn't only humans. I mean, it's nice that they are. But I'll be honest, it's too easy for everyone to look exactly the same. So honestly, this isn't a game you should play for character diversity, 'cause to put it simply: it doesn't exist. There is a lot you can do with the bodies and face shapes, but in the end, it's still easy to make a bunch of identical characters.I would recommend this game to anyone interested in a beautiful game with some good game mechanics, as an introduction to MMORPGs this is an excellent choice. Would still recommend WoW over it any day due to it's rather non-existent lore and not a huge diversity of characters who're important to stories though.

												I did practice many of those free MMORPG, and I did abandon most of them for the same reason: although the software was supposed to be free, the gameplay was always restricted for the people who don't invest in one or another way in the game, by paying items, more evoluated personages, or "Premium" rights or features in game. A few are even very odd to play freely, due to one, many, or all of these reasons :- item creation system really badly restricted,- low number of allowed works and hobbies,- trade system forbidden or strictly restricted,- many quests impossible to reach,- personages development slowered,- forbidden races or shorter number of abilities...In most of the 3D MMORPG I had to suffer one or many restrictions that made me flee from the game sooner or later, and for this reason I was quite suspicious when I installed AION, wondering if it was deserving me to spend so many time on it (the game file is very big and take few hours to download through a basic ADSL modem).But as soon as I launched the game, I realized this one as nothing common with the other MMORPG. Free number of item creation in all the work categories allowed, armors and weapons easily upgradable for everyone, any quest can be achieved if you choose to accept it, interesting gameplay, and (at least at my personal knowledge) no "Premium reserved content"... Everybody can choose to play totally freely, or to invest a few coins in a favourite item, pet or mount, to be able to get it more quickly. This is a clever way to make the money needed to maintain the game, and I really wish to say every MMORPG lovers that AION is a game that deserve their attention.

Elyos are the 'Goody two shoes', where as Asmodians are extremely tank whichever job you go for. 												I have been playing Aion since 2006 /07, i still have my original hard copy and Game time cards, i paid for this and all cause i loved it, and i still love it. The game is beautiful, and the content which it contains is fanastic. its one of those games that you really get out of it, what you put in. Since NCsoft released control of its european servers to Gameforge, admittedly the content flow and server stats have decreased alittle aswell as the amount of support and rewards you get for playing the game, if you compare the EU servers to the NA servers then installing the NA Client from AION.COM is probably a better option, ive been playing on both EU and NA servers since the game has been out, but i was originally paying to play on NA servers which has most of my characters, and which gets the most attention. However this should not stop you from downloading and playing the Steam Client which is Gameforge, Gameforge do maintain and look after their servers very well, and like any MMO the people you meet are the people you meet, they all vary. Aion is a graphicly Beautiful game, and its combat system, although alittle one sided, in the sense first hit is usually the winner ... in some cases, the combat effects and abilities are on their own level. One thing about Aion which is incredible though even from the very start and has never changed even up untill now is the Music. Aion's compisitons are just incredible and so touching, there are many moments in the game which are just made so much more amazing but the music and even now when i watch shows or hear simalar music i immeditly am drawn back to Aion. The game is not very taxing on your system thankfully even though it is an incredibly detailed piece of work, and there is a great vairty in weapons and armour aswell as cosmetic options, and their unique guild system which is called a "Legion". One of the most noticable and key features of the Legion system in the game is the emblem, where you can choose from their exising selection, or you can design and upload your own Emblem which is then usable on your cloak, Horse Armour, and on your Shield! This is a feature which i have always loved because it means that every Legion is then unique and those designs are more noticeable and rememberable. Even though the game went free to play i was worried when it happened but im not worried anymore, i am probably always gonna keep playing Aion because it holds a dear place in my Heart, and i strongly suggest that you download it and give it a try. Do remember though as i said before, that this game will only give back what you put into it, so to some it may be "grindy" but the end results show the hard work youve put in, and frankly i believe a great game is one which you get rewarded for working hard, not having it all handed to you on a silver platter. And Aion is a Great Game!

												Gry MMO są niezwykle ważnym segmentem rynku pecetowego. To jeden z nielicznych przypadków, w których można mówić o naprawdę dużych zyskach i udanych próbach radzenia sobie z piractwem. Oczywiście istnieją nielegalne serwery prawie każdej gry, ale wciąż wielu graczy decyduje się płacić abonament, żeby bawić się w komfortowych warunkach. W ciągu ostatnich kilku lat pojawiło się parę dużych tytułów z tego gatunku, które miały przyciągnąć ogromną liczbę osób i zagrozić pozycji lidera, czyli World of Warcraft. Na razie nie udało się to nikomu – nawet tak duże marki jak The Lord of the Rings Online, Warhammer Online czy Age of Conan nie zdołały wywołać większego wstrząsu. Po drugiej stronie globu, w Azji, czyli prawdziwym królestwie MMORPG, powstał Aion. Tytuł dzieła firmy NCsoft to imię boga, stwórcy tego uniwersum. Czy w samej grze można znaleźć pierwiastki boskości i geniuszu? Świat Aiona został rozdarty na trzy główne strefy, zamieszkałe przez odrębne rasy, mające jednak w pewnym sensie wspólne korzenie. Gracze mogą wcielać się w przedstawicieli dwu z nich, czyli w Asmodian i Elyosów, skłóconych ze sobą nawzajem i walczących dodatkowo z bezwzględnie złymi Balaurami (kontrolowanymi przez sztuczną inteligencję). Ci ostatni zamieszkują przestrzeń zawieszoną pomiędzy dwoma kontynentami, znaną jako Abyss. Poszatkowana w potężnym wybuchu „otchłań” składa się z pomniejszych wysepek i twierdz, znajdujących się pod silnym wpływem Aetheru, czyli magicznego surowca, pozwalającego między innymi na unoszenie się w powietrzu. To niezwykłe miejsce staje się głównym polem konfliktu trzech zwaśnionych stron, oferując graczom mieszkankę rozgrywki PvP (gracz kontra gracz) z PvE (gracz kontra otoczenie).Do naszej dyspozycji oddano cztery typy postaci, które później rozwijają się w łącznie osiem dość stereotypowych klas. Edytor postaci jest naprawdę potężnym narzędziem i pozwala wcielać w życie zarówno fantazje nastoletnich chłopców, jak i prawdziwe koszmary. Większość graczy decyduje się oczywiście na tworzenie pięknych, wysokich i umięśnionych mężczyzn oraz drobnych, uroczych dziewczyn, ale zdarzają się wyjątki. Dzięki dużej swobodzie można stworzyć i wysokiego elfa, i mikroskopijnego, brodatego krasnoluda, który biegnąc w zawrotnym tempie wywija nóżkami. Na pewno zostaną więc zaspokojone osobiste aspiracje twórcze każdego z graczy. Duży zakres skalowania poszczególnych części ciała oznacza też niestety zachodzenie na siebie niektórych elementów zbroi, włosów czy uzbrojenia, ale to już drobny szczegół. Wybierając stronę konfliktu na danym serwerze, nie możemy stworzyć postaci reprezentującej przeciwną frakcję. Szybko okazuje się więc, że przychodzi nam zmierzyć się z częścią znajomych, którzy wybrali inną ścieżkę. Zanim dochodzi do kontaktu, czeka nas sporo zadań, potworów do ubicia oraz krain do przemierzenia. Generalnie podzielony na strefy świat gry zamieszkuje kilka gatunków zwierząt i bestii, które przewijają się przez kolejne etapy fabuły. Treść zadań szybko zaczyna się powtarzać, skupiając się na absurdalnej eksterminacji wszystkiego, co się rusza (najpierw zabijamy wilki zagrażające bydłu, później zabijamy bydło dla skór). Gra jest liniowa i nie pozwala na żadne wybory czy decyzje (oprócz sporadycznych przypadków), czasami prowadząc na manowce (łatwo przykładowo ominąć małą wyspę idealną dla poziomów 20-25).
